pros: The company is strong on branding and technology. I've gained software experience with Tableau and Salesforce.com which will help me in my future endeavors. I've met some very nice people that I work with.
cons:
Too many unrealistic corporate initiatives and expectations. Cookie cutter KPI's without any regard for customer base. SFDC (Salesforce.com) is great, but upper management does not understand the amount of time it takes to record notes, tasks, requests etc. Time is needed to analyze business and to work at the pace of customers and the situations and seasonal issues that arise. From my perspective, the company is all about checking boxes so the KPI's look good. There is so much change that by the time you have figured something out it seems it's changed again. Work/ Life Balance is non-existent from my perspective. The expectation is that you get all your work done in 8-10 hours a day; which is completely unrealistic. The only way to stay at pace is to work nights and weekends and it just feels like a race on the Hamster wheel. 













 They sell "change", but they don't allow time for anyone to really develop in their role. There is so much turnover, that you don't know who to call in what dept. for what and as soon as you do that position changes. There are a lot of nice people that work here, but everyone is so busy and distracted by demands, that hasty mistakes are made all the time. These mistakes cause firedrills to resolve and often it feels like you are all alone, despite that the company touts "team-selling". Work/ Life balance is non-existent for a Sales Representative. Management will tell you to not work nights and weekends, but then if you don't meet their KPI's and other expectations, you will have to answer for it. I'm a very organized person, and I really can't keep up. It's a hamster wheel that doesn't stop. I know I am not unique in these concerns amongst my peers and everyday I question how anyone thinks this is a normal way to live.

Slow your roll and let us do our job. Stop turning us all into robots and allow our unique skills and abilities to come out by giving us TIME to prepare, plan and be creative.

review_title: Management is losing control of operations
pros:
US Foods was a good company when I start there. I worked at the Milwaukee division for nearly four years. There was plenty of work, without being overloaded. There were good routes and management actually tried to keep things running smoothly. After they acquired Dierks Waukesha, it turned into a downward spiral.

They pay well for the work it is, but you are going to work for your money. 

They had good benefits. 

It's local and you will be home every night.

The equipment is newer and in good condition. They also have on site mechanics that maintain vehicles.
cons:
After they acquired Dierks Waukesha, the company went into a downward spiral. Management began to lose control of the organization. This was more than just growing pains. Every day turned into a fourteen hour day. I was working 65+ hours in four days and being asked to work off days. Keys to customers locations were being lost. When I reported to my supervisor that I did not have the keys for my first two stops, he replied, "No body cares anymore." There is poor communication between other departments and transportation resulting in critical information not reaching the driver. An example of this is a customer changed his door and lock. They put the new key in the mail box. The sales rep knew this, but never bothered to tell transportation so the driver would know. So you waste an hour playing phone tag to find out the key was there the whole time. 

For various reasons, a lot of the management that was at US Foods prior to the acquisition decided to leave the company. The result was that a lot of the management that was at Dierks Waukesha (the company that failed) ended up in management at US Foods after the acquisition. The ironic part of this is that I worked at Dierks Waukesha and left because the place was a soup sandwhich. After the management came over, it looked more and more like Dierks Waukesha every day. 

I began to experience the transportation manager and other supervisors asking me to violate company policies. 

Routes began to decline in quality. I heard a number of drivers who had been there upwards of twenty years or more comment that they had never seen the place so bad. 

The few weeks prior to me leaving, about five other drivers also quit. 

A lot of the operational problems are the result of not properly staffing the place. There is a lot of turnover because it's a very physical, hands on job. Not many people are willing to stay there because there are too many other trucking jobs that are local, no touch, and pay well enough that it's difficult to justify staying there long. 

When one driver quit, the work load increased for everyone else. It created a domino effect where each driver quitting became the breaking point for other drivers. 

There was also zero truth in routing. I started each day by looking at my route to figure out all the mistakes I had to fix. I would be given an hour and fifteen minutes to make a drive that takes at least two hours. We were always scheduled to make deliveries outside of customer's delivery windows. Routes cannot be scheduled to exceed fourteen hours, so they manipulate the times to keep the route times down.

Cameras in the trucks and stupid policies about them like not being able to take a drink of water when the truck is moving (even in parking lots).

There is very little opportunity for career advancement if you're looking to get into management.
Advice to Management
Make the tough decisions to staff the place properly. 
Stop letting "customer service" be an excuse for poor treatment of drivers. Drivers who are not treated well by management are not going to give good customer service. Open your eyes to how dangerous things are getting because drivers are overworked. Hold people, including supervisors, accountable and enforce your own policies. Losing customer keys and truck keys is an absolute operational failure. Policies are in place to maintain accountability of keys, but those policies are not being followed. When this is brought up to a supervisor, it's blown off, not realizing, or not caring about the huge problems it creates for the other drivers.
